channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: GOP Sen. Lisa Murkowski urges colleagues to reach deal as SNAP benefits dry up
item.description: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with Sen. Lisa Murkowski about the possible loss of SNAP benefits due to the shutdown.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with Sen. Lisa Murkowski about the possible loss of SNAP benefits due to the shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levitt

item.title: Disputed election result in Cameroon fuels tensions with younger generation
item.description: Driving through barricades and burned banks in Douala: Cameroon's disputed election sparks a showdown with its young generation.
item.content:encoded: Driving through barricades and burned banks in Douala: Cameroon's disputed election sparks a showdown with its young generation.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Akinwotu

item.title: Louisiana set aside funds to bridge the SNAP gap -- but not everyone will get some
item.description: On the eve of federal SNAP benefits hitting people's accounts, Louisiana is jumping in to fill the gap for the 1 in 5 state residents who use the program, but only for some of them.
item.content:encoded: On the eve of federal SNAP benefits hitting people's accounts, Louisiana is jumping in to fill the gap for the 1 in 5 state residents who use the program, but only for some of them.
item.dc:creator: Brooke Thorington

item.title: Public health leaders are meeting to figure out how to counter the MAHA movement
item.description: Public health leaders and researchers are kicking off a meeting in Washington, D.C., to discuss how to counter what they see as dangerous ideas coming from the Make America Healthy Again movement.
item.content:encoded: Public health leaders and researchers are kicking off a meeting in Washington, D.C., to discuss how to counter what they see as dangerous ideas coming from the Make America Healthy Again movement.
item.dc:creator: Pien Huang

item.title: Judges intervene before SNAP cutoff
item.description: A federal judge has given the Trump administration until Monday to consider whether to pay at least partial SNAP food benefits -- even though millions of people will be without aid starting tomorrow.
item.content:encoded: A federal judge has given the Trump administration until Monday to consider whether to pay at least partial SNAP food benefits -- even though millions of people will be without aid starting tomorrow.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Ludden

item.title: Some U.S. troops get paid today, but National Guard faces additional complications
item.description: President Trump pledged to pay the troops today, but what about in the weeks ahead? The military is feeling the pressure of the shutdown, and for the National Guard, it's even more complicated.
item.content:encoded: President Trump pledged to pay the troops today, but what about in the weeks ahead? The military is feeling the pressure of the shutdown, and for the National Guard, it's even more complicated.
item.dc:creator: Jay Price

item.title: Tariffs are intended to bring furniture jobs back to N.C., but it won't be easy
item.description: North Carolina furniture makers say new tariffs may help them compete against imports, but their industry relies on global supplies that are getting more expensive.
item.content:encoded: North Carolina furniture makers say new tariffs may help them compete against imports, but their industry relies on global supplies that are getting more expensive.
item.dc:creator: Paul Garber

item.title: As the shutdown grinds on, Trump isn't sticking around to negotiate
item.description: President Trump has spent nearly two weeks outside of Washington, D.C., since the shutdown began on Oct. 1
item.content:encoded: President Trump has spent nearly two weeks outside of Washington, D.C., since the shutdown began on Oct. 1
item.dc:creator: Tamara Keith

item.title: New Music Friday: Snocaps
item.description: Snocaps, the new band of Katie and Allison Crutchfield, released a surprise album today. The sisters, who have been making music together for more than two decades, sound better than ever.
item.content:encoded: Snocaps, the new band of Katie and Allison Crutchfield, released a surprise album today. The sisters, who have been making music together for more than two decades, sound better than ever.
item.dc:creator: Kira Wakeam

item.title: Main Character of the Week: Mr. Fantasy
item.description: NPR's Mia Venkat explains to All Things Considered host Scott Detrow who the internet has been obsessed with this week.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Mia Venkat explains to All Things Considered host Scott Detrow who the internet has been obsessed with this week.
item.dc:creator: Mia Venkat
